meaning_mnemonic:
This is a <kanji>build</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>, or perhaps a <kanji>build</kanji>ing <kanji>thing</kanji>. In other words, a <vocabulary>building</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary>. 

建物 is a very general word that can refer to any kind of building, including residential buildings, commercial buildings, or public facilities.
I will <kanji>judge</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> you. This is an <vocabulary>examination</vocabulary>, so we'll see if you pass.

This word has <kanji>judge</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> in it, so it has something to do with <vocabulary>judgment</vocabulary>. It's usually used in sports, so it's the <vocabulary>referee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>umpire</vocabulary>, depending on your sport of choice.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>undress</kanji> and the verb is <vocabulary>to undress</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>cheap</kanji> <kanji>value</kanji>d item comes at a <vocabulary>low price</vocabulary>. What a good deal!

A <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>value</kanji>. If you paid for something that had a tall value, it would have a <vocabulary>high price</vocabulary>.

This word is often used when something sells for a comparatively high price. Like when a stock is hitting highs, or goods are sold for higher than the average market price, or something can fetch a high price at auction.
A <kanji>standard</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji> is just one of the <vocabulary>rule</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>regulation</vocabulary>s. Nothing weird about these rules.

A <kanji>standard</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is the <vocabulary>rule</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>law</vocabulary> you have to follow. With these standard laws comes <vocabulary>discipline</vocabulary>. If you don't have these it will be chaos!

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you'd think it's probably an adjective. However in this case, it's a noun. What's the noun form of <kanji>different</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>difference</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>different</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be different</vocabulary>... and of course, to be different is also <vocabulary>to be wrong</vocabulary> in Japan. Don't be different!
<kanji>Possible</kanji> to <kanji>burn</kanji> ゴミ (garbage). This is <vocabulary>burnable garbage</vocabulary>.
The word 営業 is <kanji>business</kanji>. The verb version of that (to do a business) becomes <vocabulary>to run a business</vocabulary>.
If 伝統 is "tradition," then adding a 的 (<kanji>-al</kanji>) to it would make it <vocabulary>traditional</vocabulary>.
Remember how 誕生 is <kanji>birth</kanji>? If you add <kanji>day</kanji> on there, you have a <vocabulary>birthday</vocabulary>. Happy birthday!
寝坊 is <kanji>oversleep</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to oversleep</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>past</kanji> <kanji>shape</kanji> is how things were in the past. To describe those things (like you would with an adjective, aka 形容詞), you'd use <vocabulary>past tense</vocabulary>.

過ぎる is <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary>. When you pass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>after</vocabulary>, as in "after 5pm", and <vocabulary>past</vocabulary>, as in "past sixty".
Your <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>plan</kanji> is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your <vocabulary>counter plan</vocabulary>.
These <kanji>view</kanji>s that have <kanji>merit</kanji> (価値) are your <vocabulary>values</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>group</kanji> that <kanji>roots for</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>rooting section</vocabulary> or <vocabulary> cheer squad</vocabulary>. Go go go you!

応援団 tend to wear black school uniforms and support their team with lively chants and energetic performances. They can also have cheerleaders with pom-poms, but those are usually just called チアリーダー.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary>. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike 担う which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.
You <kanji>carry</kanji> everyone else and you are always <kanji>right</kanji>. With these traits, you are <vocabulary>in charge</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>lose</kanji>. Because of that, you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> this <vocabulary>burden</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>responsibility</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>half</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> sale is when things are <vocabulary>half price</vocabulary>. Cheap!
A <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> is a <vocabulary>large amount</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>large sum</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>yearly amount</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>month</kanji>'s <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>monthly amount</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>determine</kanji>d <kanji>amount</kanji> is an amount that is fixed, aka a <vocabulary>fixed amount</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>fixed sum</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>flat rate</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>remainder</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>remaining amount</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>balance</vocabulary>.

For example, you will see this word used when displaying the balance of a prepaid card or e-money, like an IC card.
<kanji>Manufacture</kanji>d <kanji>goods</kanji> are <vocabulary>manufactured goods</vocabulary>. What does that end up being? A <vocabulary>product</vocabulary>.

A place where you <kanji>manufacture</kanji> and <kanji>make</kanji> is a place where <vocabulary>manufacturing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>production</vocabulary> are done. So many things getting made.
<kanji>Tree</kanji> <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d items are <vocabulary>wooden</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>made from wood</vocabulary>.
Things that are <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d in <kanji>Japan</kanji> (日本) are <vocabulary>made in Japan</vocabulary>. Good quality stuff, that is.
China (中国) <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d items are <vocabulary>made in China</vocabulary>.
<kanji>America</kanji> <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d is something that is <vocabulary>made in USA</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>made in America</vocabulary>.
By my <kanji>self</kanji> at <kanji>home</kanji> I <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d this. It is <vocabulary>homemade</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>transport</kanji> things and they <kanji>exit</kanji> from your country, you are <vocabulary>export</vocabulary>ing them.
<kanji>Transport</kanji> of <kanji>blood</kanji>. Only time you do this is during a <vocabulary>blood transfusion</vocabulary>.

These are <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>burn</kanji>able garbages (ごみ). Pay attention to this on signs when you throw things away. You want to put the right things into <vocabulary>nonburnable garbage</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>celebrate</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to celebrate</vocabulary>. When you burn this word, you should 祝う!

A <kanji>celebrate</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a day you get off to celebrate something awesome. More specifically, this is known as a <vocabulary>national holiday</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>public holiday</vocabulary>.

祝日 refers to officially recognized holidays people get off from school or (hopefully) work. In Japan, that's stuff like New Year's Day, the emperor's birthday, and the Golden Week holidays, among others.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deliver</kanji> so the verb vocab version here is <vocabulary>to be delivered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary>. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "<reading>coo'</reading>" (く), it arrived.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>narrow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>narrow</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Remember how 時計 is <kanji>watch</kanji>? An <kanji>arm</kanji> is now there too, making this a <vocabulary>wristwatch</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

腰 refers to the <vocabulary>waist</vocabulary> area around the top part of the hip bone — the part that sticks out when you put your hands on your hips. It includes the sides and the back as well, which is why this can also mean <vocabulary>lower back</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>touch</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to touch something</vocabulary>.

触る is used when someone does the touching. It's not used to describe objects touching each other.

Note that 触る can be used with either the particle に or を, like 手に触る or 手を触る (to touch a hand). Using に simply marks the location you touch, while using を highlights your action of touching that specific area or object. So the former is intransitive and the latter is transitive, though there's some debate about that.

The <kanji>angle</kanji> of the <kanji>touch</kanji> is important with an <vocabulary>antenna</vocabulary>. Think about antennae. An ant's antennae wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennae touching your arm to figure out who you are.

Note that 触角 refers to the antennae of insects, crustaceans, and certain other arthropods, rather than to TV or radio antennas.
Your <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>touch</kanji> is your <vocabulary>touch sense</vocabulary> (or simply just <vocabulary>touch</vocabulary>).

When you give information its <kanji>place</kanji>, it's <kanji>put on</kanji> record. That means it has been <vocabulary>recorded</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>published</vocabulary> in a particular publication.

所載 is a formal term that is commonly used immediately after the publication's name to specify where the information is kept.

Please <kanji>write down</kanji> and <kanji>put on</kanji> paper the facts, so we have a <vocabulary>record</vocabulary> of them. 

記載 refers to information that is recorded in some manner, typically in written, printed, or digital form.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's also an intransitive verb, meaning the action happens on its own, you don't do it. The kanji itself means <kanji>place on</kanji>, and this means <vocabulary>to be placed on</vocabulary>.

載る is also often used to refer to something being included in a written document or publication and so can also mean <vocabulary>to be recorded</vocabulary>, as in 新聞に載る (to be recorded in a newspaper) or 教科書に載る (to be recorded in a textbook).

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>layer</kanji> more? One whole layer? It must be <vocabulary>much more</vocabulary> important than we thought. Let's pay <vocabulary>all the more</vocabulary> attention, in that case.

This word is often written in kana, but you'll see it in kanji too.

This is a word that's attached to other things indicating the <vocabulary>layer of</vocabulary> something (or just <vocabulary>layer</vocabulary>). It has essentially the same meaning as the kanji it comes from, <kanji>layer</kanji>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You learned that 的 on the end of a word means “-al” or “-like”. So what is <kanji>rule</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> <kanji>-like</kanji>? It’s a model that follows all the rules. It's the normal model. It’s <vocabulary>typical</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> of something isn't usually very good. It's rough. It's a <vocabulary>prototype</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>metropolis</kanji> <kanji>agency</kanji> is the government that controls the metropolitan area. Their office is in the <vocabulary>metropolitan government building</vocabulary>.

They <kanji>warn</kanji> people and they <kanji>look at</kanji> crime, and they even have an <kanji>agency</kanji>. Who is it? It's Tokyo's <vocabulary>metropolitan police department</vocabulary>. 

The 警 here is actually short for 警察 (police). The word 警視 itself used to refer to officials who oversee police operations, but now it's mostly used in the 警視庁 agency name. Basically, this is the big agency that employs and oversees all the Tokyo metropolitan police!

Unlike the 警視庁, who look at things, this is just the <kanji>police officer</kanji> (警察) <kanji>agency</kanji>. Just the general police agency of the whole country, making them part of the <vocabulary>National Police Agency</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>government</kanji> <kanji>government office</kanji> is a <vocabulary>government office</vocabulary>. Did I mention government?
I will <kanji>look at</kanji> <kanji>nothing</kanji>. I am going <vocabulary>to ignore</vocabulary> you.
You <kanji>look at</kanji> things and <kanji>memorize</kanji> them via your sight, using your <vocabulary>sense of sight</vocabulary>.

When you can <kanji>look at</kanji> things that are <kanji>near</kanji> well but you can't see things far away, you have <vocabulary>nearsightedness</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>shortsightedness</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>myopia</vocabulary>. Good to get those eyes checked out occasionally.

When you can <kanji>look at</kanji> <kanji>far</kanji> things, but not near things, you have <vocabulary>farsightedness</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>longsightedness</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>hyperopia</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>distinction</kanji>, and the verb version here means… a million things. Let's just focus on a few common meanings. Things with distinction tend to stick out from the others. They tend <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary>, you know? And if you imagine shining a beam of light on something, that light tends <vocabulary>to project</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to extend outward</vocabulary>. It sticks out, shines on something, then makes that thing more distinct too. 

That's why you can say 光が差す (light shines), かげが差す (a shadow is cast), 指差す (to point at), or even カサを差す (to open and raise an umbrella). Basically, 差す usually has to do with causing something <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary>, either by shining or projecting outward.
You make a <kanji>distinction</kanji> between people and based off that you <kanji>separate</kanji> the people. This is terrible! Why so much <vocabulary>discrimination</vocabulary>?

You <kanji>mix</kanji>, but there's a <kanji>distinction</kanji> as to where you mix at this <kanji>point</kanji>. Where is this point? It can be found when two streets cross, at an <vocabulary>intersection</vocabulary>, also known as a <vocabulary>crossing</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>distinction</kanji> is how you tell apart time zones. It is the <vocabulary>time difference</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>pipe</kanji> of <kanji>reason</kanji>. Imagine someone holding this pipe. It always leads to the correct decision because it is the pipe of reason. Those who have this pipe are in a higher rank than you. They are the <vocabulary>management</vocabulary>, and by using this pipe of reason they're able to make good management decisions.
The <kanji>pipe</kanji>s that hold your <kanji>blood</kanji> are your <vocabulary>blood vessel</vocabulary>s, or your <vocabulary>vein</vocabulary>s.
The <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> is what you're going up against. It's your <vocabulary>target</vocabulary> because you're heading towards this phenomenon you're versusing against.
A <kanji>present time</kanji> <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>phenomenon</vocabulary> whether it's in the present or in the future or in the past.
The <kanji>energy</kanji> <kanji>phenomenon</kanji>. That's when energy is doing stuff in the sky and nobody understands it. That's the <vocabulary>weather</vocabulary> for you.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>quantity</kanji>, but you don't "to quantity." To figure out the quantity, however, you have <vocabulary>to measure</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to weigh</vocabulary> whatever it is you want to get the quantity of.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>quantity</kanji> is a <vocabulary>large quantity</vocabulary>. Kind of like the <vocabulary>large number</vocabulary> of words you're learning here now. A <vocabulary>huge amount</vocabulary>. Well done you.

A <kanji>determine</kanji>d <kanji>quantity</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fixed quantity</vocabulary>.

定量 is a formal word commonly used in academic, technical, financial, and business contexts for discussing research, experiments, or data analysis. You usually encounter it as 定量的 (quantitative) or 定量化 (quantification).
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>boundary</kanji> is that country's <vocabulary>national border</vocabulary>. Be careful about crossing it if you're carrying bananas. The border police seem to hate when you tell them you're carrying a banana in your pants when they ask you if you're bringing any fruits back. No idea why.
The <kanji>boundary</kanji> separates <kanji>world</kanji>s. It is a <vocabulary>boundary</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>loop</kanji> that makes up the <kanji>boundary</kanji> of this area holds in the <vocabulary>environment</vocabulary>, at least this particular one.
A <kanji>container</kanji> used by the <kanji>military</kanji> is probably going to be used as a <vocabulary>weapon</vocabulary>. After all, that's what the military does... weapons.

If you take the <kanji>road</kanji> of the <kanji>military</kanji> you're going to have to fight a lot. Back in the day, this involved learning <vocabulary>martial arts</vocabulary> to fight with. Remember, just wax off.
A <kanji>military</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is a <vocabulary>samurai</vocabulary>. This is how most people say "samurai" in Japanese.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>quality</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is worth a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary>. A low quality problem however... don't ask the question. There are stupid questions, after all.
A <kanji>product</kanji>'s <kanji>quality</kanji> is in its <vocabulary>material quality</vocabulary>. If the materials aren't any good then the product isn't either.
<kanji>Good</kanji> <kanji>quality</kanji> is always <vocabulary>good quality</vocabulary>. Don't skimp!

Your <kanji>special</kanji> <kanji>quality</kanji> is your <vocabulary>characteristic</vocabulary>s or your <vocabulary>trait</vocabulary>s.

This is a formal word that refers to special properties that only a certain thing possesses, like the properties of steel as a material, or a certain person’s nature.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mention</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word often used in writing.

When you <kanji>Write down</kanji> and <kanji>mention</kanji> what happened, you're <vocabulary>writing down</vocabulary> a <vocabulary>description</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>account</vocabulary> of it. 

記述 simply means writing things down (whether by hand or by typing), usually to have an objective written record about something. 記述 can also refer to the text that's been written.

<kanji>Above</kanji> <kanji>mention</kanji>s are <vocabulary>above mentioned</vocabulary>. Look above to see where I mentioned it, okay?

Note that 上述 is a word commonly used in formal writing such as reports, academic papers, or business documents.

When you <kanji>present</kanji> something and <kanji>offer</kanji> it to someone, you're kindly <vocabulary>offering</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>providing</vocabulary> it to them.

提供 is a relatively formal word that refers to offering or providing something you have for someone else's benefit — like giving resources, services, funds, or information.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>offer</kanji>, and this verb version means <vocabulary>to make an offering</vocabulary>.

供える means <vocabulary>to offer</vocabulary> something, usually to a god, Buddha, or someone who has passed away. For example, you might 花を供える (offer flowers) at a grave or altar.

A <kanji>child</kanji> often has to <kanji>accompany</kanji> someone else when they go places, because they're… a <vocabulary>child</vocabulary>. Can't have all those kids running around unaccompanied, can we?

I want to <kanji>expand</kanji> my business. I want to <kanji>show</kanji> my goods. I want to do this in a place where everyone <kanji>meet</kanji>s up to do these things. You can do this in a <vocabulary>trade show</vocabulary>.
Let's <kanji>depart</kanji> from this place and <kanji>expand</kanji> it out. To do that we'll have <vocabulary>to develop</vocabulary> it.
To <kanji>expand</kanji> and <kanji>open</kanji>. Just imagine something happening like this. This is when something is <vocabulary>unfolding</vocabulary> or in <vocabulary>development</vocabulary>.

If <kanji>intimacy</kanji> <kanji>expand</kanji>s to something, that thing is <vocabulary>confidential</vocabulary>. Try visualizing intimacy as a sort of gooey liquid, expanding and covering a letter, and making that letter confidential.

親展 is generally written on the front of envelopes to indicate that only the intended recipient should read its contents.

<kanji>Sell</kanji>, <kanji>sell</kanji>, sell. This is the attitude you need if you want to work in <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary> or do <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary>. You have to work on your <vocabulary>selling</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Automatic</kanji> (自動) <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji>. The machine sells things by itself, basically. This is a <vocabulary>vending machine</vocabulary>. There is a shorter version of this, but good to learn the long one first :)

Things you <kanji>sell</kanji> that <kanji>pass through</kanji> the world to get to you are probably <vocabulary>mail order</vocabulary>. You order them and they get zoomed off to you, passing through all kinds of space to arrive at your door.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>stock</kanji> <kanji>ritual</kanji> is the dance we do in the modern world around <vocabulary>stock</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>share</vocabulary>s of different companies. Buy! Sell! Buy! Sell!
Remember 寝坊 and how it means <kanji>oversleep</kanji>? Someone who oversleeps in the <kanji>morning</kanji> is someone who's a <vocabulary>late riser</vocabulary>.
Remember how 営業 means "business"? Well, if you're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of running a business, it means you're <vocabulary>open for business</vocabulary>.

置く is <kanji>to put down</kanji> something. So a <kanji>location</kanji> where you put something down is a <vocabulary>place to put something</vocabulary>.

置き場 often follows another word, signifying it's the designated area where that specific item should be stored or parked. For example, 自転車置き場.
主観 is <kanji>subjectivity</kanji>. So when something moves towards subjectivity it is becoming <vocabulary>subjective</vocabulary>.
You know that 援助 is <kanji>assistance</kanji> or <kanji>aid</kanji>. So the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to assist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to aid</vocabulary>.

応援 is <kanji>aid</kanji> and <kanji>root for</kanji>, but for this verb the "root for" one is going to be more on the money. You can call this <vocabulary>to root for</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to cheer on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cheer for</vocabulary>.
You know about 大統領 (<kanji>president</kanji>), right? Well, this is the <kanji>vice</kanji> version of the president, aka the <vocabulary>vice president</vocabulary>.
You remember 提案, which means <kanji>proposition</kanji>? Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to propose</vocabulary>.
To <kanji>support</kanji> and <kanji>aid</kanji> is <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Sightseeing</kanji> (観光) <kanji>guest</kanji>s are <vocabulary>tourist</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>sightseer</vocabulary>s.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stab</kanji> so the verb vocab version must also be <vocabulary>to stab</vocabulary>.

Wondering how it's different from 刺す? 突く refers to the act of pushing or pressing something with a tip of an object, often done forcefully and swiftly. So when you use 突く as in "to stab," your focus is on the forcefulness of the action. On the other hand, 刺す focuses more on the actual act of piercing into something or someone with a sharp thing. 

This is why 突く can be be translated many ways, like <vocabulary>to poke</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to jab</vocabulary>, and many more.

When you're <kanji>renew</kanji>ing what you're saying, you're adding onto it, which makes this <vocabulary>furthermore</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>further</vocabulary>. 

This is one of those good paragraph or sentence-starting essay words, which is how you'll often see it used!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>burn</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to burn something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to set on fire</vocabulary>.
<kanji>All</kanji> of the <kanji>amount</kanji> is your <vocabulary>total</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>arm</kanji> is your <vocabulary>left arm</vocabulary>.

You previously learned this kanji with three different meanings. In vocabulary form, it just has one of these meanings, <vocabulary>framed picture</vocabulary>! Similarly, it can just mean <vocabulary>picture</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>frame</vocabulary> too.

When you want to use your <kanji>finger</kanji> to explain the <kanji>distinction</kanji> between more than one thing, you need <vocabulary>to point at</vocabulary> it. Otherwise the person you're talking to won't be able to tell which one you're talking about.

In general, 指差す specifically means using one’s index finger to physically point at something or someone.
The <kanji>real</kanji> <kanji>quality</kanji> of something is its <vocabulary>essence</vocabulary>, or its <vocabulary>true nature</vocabulary>. Whether it's good or bad is a different story.
A <kanji>material</kanji> you can <kanji>burn</kanji> is called <vocabulary>fuel</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Both</kanji> <kanji>arm</kanji>s are <vocabulary>both arms</vocabulary>!
You want to <kanji>transport</kanji> something by <kanji>send</kanji>ing it? Well, that's <vocabulary>transportation</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>price</kanji> <kanji>tag</kanji> is... a <vocabulary>price tag</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Half</kanji> <kanji>sleeve</kanji>s is just another name for <vocabulary>short sleeves</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>sleeve</kanji>s are <vocabulary>long sleeves</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>construct</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to build something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to construct something</vocabulary>.
